@RomneyWeir @TW11Harbour @ThamesPathNT @Tidal_Thames95 @EnvAgencySE @MariaHerlihyEA @RiverThames Remind me when I'm sober and I can check which reaches are which blocks and which are independent. Although tonight I'm off duty and wondering if more Christmas cake is a bad idea.

@TW11Harbour @ThamesPathNT @Tidal_Thames95 @EnvAgencySE @MariaHerlihyEA @RiverThames Yep - we're saying the same thing from a slightly different viewpoint - #Hambleden to #Boveney reaches are a block, and I was seeing them as each of the reaches below Hambleden do the same as the reach above (although #Marlow sometimes does its own thing)

@ThamesPathNT @Tidal_Thames95 @EnvAgencySE @MariaHerlihyEA @RiverThames Sorry to not have explained - on the non tidal #Thames a reach is the stretch of river between 2 locks, named after the lower lock. So #Romney reach is from me to #Boveney, Boveney reach is from Boveney lock/weir to #Bray
@RomneyWeir @ThamesPathNT @EnvAgencySE @MariaHerlihyEA @RiverThames Thank you. That's very interesting to know.

@ThamesPathNT @RomneyWeir @Tidal_Thames95 @EnvAgencySE @MariaHerlihyEA @RiverThames Some lock sites on the Thames trigger as part of a 'block' of weirs whereby the whole block will all go red or yellow when the trigger site goes.

urls.title: River Thames Conditions
urls.description: Welcome to the Environment Agency's online River Thames conditions update service which displays our current advice to river users. We display warning boards at our locks to inform river users of conditions that may make navigating difficult and dangerous. This page shows our current advice for each reach of the river between Cricklade and Teddington. We will update this information regularly when warning boards are being displayed at locks and as river conditions change. Upstream of St John's Lock No
